subject: Re: Cole's Funny Picture Book
msgSnippet: Steve, I think you re right about there not being many (or any) books that have been completely translated into QuikScript... but that was one of the reasons I
messageBody:
Steve,

I think you're right about there not being many (or any) books that
have been completely translated into QuikScript... but that was one of
the reasons I wrote my "QsConverter" program (see the "Files"
section). This program will run on a PC with Windows XP or 2000, but
not on Windows95; wasn't tested on any other operating systems). It
allows you to type or "cut and paste" any "plain" text you want and
then hit "Convert" to display the text in QuikScript. This will allow
you to generate lots of reading material on any subject you're
interested in.

Before I went on my last vacation, I converted 5 or 6 stories that I
found on-line, then read them (in QuikScript) at the beach. The only
problem I ran into, was that the dictionary that's used for the
translations, is an Oxford English dictionary (not an American
dictionary), so it doesn't have exactly the same pronunciations I
would have used. Most words are the same, but a few aren't. I got
used to the "British" sounds pretty quickly... if you have the
patience, you can edit the dictionary yourself to change the
conversions to whatever you like.

If you have an electronic version of "Wind in the Willows" it might be
easier to convert it using the "QsConverter" program, then edit it to
get the exact pronunciations you want.

Jeff

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "steveb_667" <sbartok1632@e...>
wrote:
> To my understanding, Cole's Funny Book has a section in it that
> explains Quikscript (much like Kingsley Read's manual).
>
> As for books written with the Quikscript alphabet, there have been
> none thus far that I know of. In fact, I'm not sure if there's a
> completed work for either Shavian or Quikscript besides "Androcles &
> The Lion." I remember a Shavian site that had some lengthy writings
> transcribed but they were not actual books (one of them was a booklet
> about how to drive a car). There also seems to have been an (now
> abandoned) attempt to transcribe the Bible in Shavian.
>
> I have been slowly transcribing the book "Wind in the Willows" for my
> own enjoyment, but it is far from complete.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Joe" <allegrox_2000@y...> wrote:
> > A search on ABE Books (http://www.abebooks.com) yields several hits.
> > I'm not familiar with this book, though. Is it entirely in QS, or
does
> > it just refer to it?
> > I'm also curious of how many books have been printed in or about
> > Quickscript, besides Read's manual.
> >
> > Regards,
> > Joseph Spicer

Steve,

I think you're right about there not being many (or any) books that
have been completely translated into QuikScript... but that was one of
the reasons I wrote my "QsConverter" program (see the "Files"
section).  This program will run on a PC with Windows XP or 2000, but
not on Windows95; wasn't tested on any other operating systems).  It
allows you to type or "cut and paste" any "plain" text you want and
then hit "Convert" to display the text in QuikScript.  This will allow
you to generate lots of reading material on any subject you're
interested in.

Before I went on my last vacation, I converted 5 or 6 stories that I
found on-line, then read them (in QuikScript) at the beach.  The only
problem I ran into, was that the dictionary that's used for the
translations, is an Oxford English dictionary (not an American
dictionary), so it doesn't have exactly the same pronunciations I
would have used.  Most words are the same, but a few aren't.  I got
used to the "British" sounds pretty quickly... if you have the
patience, you can edit the dictionary yourself to change the
conversions to whatever you like.

If you have an electronic version of "Wind in the Willows" it might be
easier to convert it using the "QsConverter" program, then edit it to
get the exact pronunciations you want.

Jeff
